abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second SCARP
            Transition Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, GOP provinces should take the lead in the
            preparation of provincial projects and designate staff to
            ensure quality control and involve all stakeholders. Second,
            a structured social mobilization program and
            multi-disciplinary approach to project implementation is
            essential for the success of irrigated agriculture projects.
            Third, farmer training should be an integral part of project
            design and initiated early in the project. Fourth,
            consideration should be given to developing micro-credit to
            help small farmers pay upfront contributions for CTWs and
            watercourse improvements. Fifth, arrangements for internal
            and external monitoring and impact evaluation activities
            should be operationalized from the start of the project and
            the quality of data collection and collation should be
            closely supervised. Finally, continuity of competent and
            motivated key project staff improves project implementation.
